entry.title: Process Purchase Requisition Centrally app Display material description and number
entry.content:
Hello Dear Support Team,

 

When viewing requisitions in the Process Purchase Requisition Centrally Pstandard descriptions and numbers appear together in fields such as material group and material. Below is an example of a material number. Our customer only wants to see the numbers and not the descriptions. This will make it easier for them to run reports when they export the requisitions to Excel. Can you help us resolve this issue?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Process Purchase Requisition Centrally app Display ma...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

Unfortunately, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition does not provide standard configuration options to separate material numbers from descriptions in the Process Purchase Requisitions Centrally app. The system displays material information in the combined format "Description (Material Number)" by design.

Current System Behavior: The Process Purchase Requisitions Centrally app displays materials and material groups with both descriptions and numbers together in a single field,

Available Workarounds:

Option 1: Export and Post-Process in Excel

  • Export the purchase requisition data to Excel from the Process Purchase Requisitions Centrally app .
  • Use Excel functions to separate the material number from the description:

Option 2: Use Alternative Apps for Reporting

  • Consider using the Monitor Purchase Requisition Items Centrally app  which may provide different display options
  • The Central Purchase Requisition Item Types app offers analytical views that might better suit your reporting needs

Option 3: Custom Field Enhancement  you may be able to use the Custom Fields and Logic app to create additional fields that could store material numbers separately  However, this would require:

  • Creating custom fields through the Custom Fields tab
  • Using the business context: Central Procurement: Purchase Requisitions (MM_PUR_HUB_PR_ITEM)
  • This approach would need validation to ensure it meets your specific requirements

Technical Limitation: The combined display format is part of the standard SAP Fiori design for material fields across multiple apps. Similar behavior exists in other purchasing applications where material descriptions and numbers are displayed together.

Recommendation: For immediate needs, the Excel post-processing approach would be the most practical solution. For long-term requirements, consider submitting a feature request through the SAP Customer Influence Portal to request separate display options for material numbers and descriptions in the Process Purchase Requisitions Centrally app

SAP offers an opportunity for SAP S/4HANA Cloud customers to submit improvement requests using this link: Homepage - Customer Influence (sap.com). Customer Influence (CIS) is a platform where customers can suggest features that they would like to see in future SAP HANA releases.

Please refer to the SAP KBA ##2963059 - How to Submit Feature Requests for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Product.

 

Thanks and Regards

SAP SUPPORT

entry.title: Universal Component Breakdown (UCB): Revolutionizing Product Cost Management and Transparency Pt. 1
entry.content:
Co-authored by @EvaWang  and Jessica Dewald

 

What's UCB?

Universal Component Breakdown (UCB) offers comprehensive transparency and insights into the cost structures of products, specifically targeting the costs of goods manufactured and sold. This innovation addresses a critical business need, enabling companies to better understand and manage cost factors that influence product profitability and company contribution margins. UCB will continuously replace the existing product costing capability with an innovative and streamlined solution tailored for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 
 
With the initial version of the product cost breakdown you have a solid foundation to obtain those insights. 
The functionalities of UCB will be gradually enhanced in the coming releases. The result will be a fully integrated solution providing cost transparency from planning and procurement to manufacturing and sales across even complex multi-level value chains. 
In the past, controllers had blurry vision when it came to advising the business on product profitability due to aggregation of things like allocated costs. With the new component breakdown types, opportunities to take action come into focus and new questions can be answered with the data to back them up. 

If you’re new to this topic, you’re in the right place to get answers and find further resources on the following questions: 

  • Which functionalities are included with scope item 7NH, and which additional scope items are required? (See sections What’s Covered by Scope Item 7NH and Scope Activation and Dependencies)

  • How is it set up?  (See sections Scope Activation and Dependencies and SAP Standard Content)
  • What’s the default content and what can you do in terms of configuration? (See section SAP Standard Content)
  • How does it work in an end-to-end scenario? (See part 2 of our blog series)
  • What’s the relationship between UCB and the existing cost component split solution (based on scope item BEG)? (See part 2 of this blog series) 

The UCB solution is currently represented by two scope items. Each of them has a different focus area:  

  • 7NH: Product Cost Breakdown in Plan/Actual Value Flow
  • 6VN: Product-Related Carbon Emission Quantities

In the following section, we'll focus on the product cost breakdown (7NH).

 

What’s Covered by Scope Item 7NH: Product Cost Breakdown in Plan/Actual Value Flow

In this blog, we will give you an overview of the key benefits of scope item 7NH (Product Cost Breakdown in Plan/Actual Value Flow) and will also highlight the new features that have been released with S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition 2508.  

First of all, scope item 7NH enables the production cost breakdown and origin cost breakdown in the plan and actual value flow for a manufactured product with quantity structure and calculates material standard cost estimates.  

Now let’s take a look at what these breakdown types include: 

  • The production cost breakdown provides an explanation of the cost of goods manufactured (COGM) from the point of view of the manufacturing process (material usage, internal activities, external activities, etc.). 
  • The origin cost breakdown is an alternative way of showing the cost of goods manufactured of a product.  You can review the original production factors to understand the impact of changes to your primary costs. These changes include increases in energy prices, higher wage costs, or adjustments in depreciation rules. Without the origin cost breakdown, these costs would be subsumed in the activity rate and simply grouped as production activity costs. 
  • Both the cost of goods manufactured (COGM) breakdown and the cost of goods sold (COGS) breakdown are specific views that you can display for a sold product. They can either be based on the origin cost breakdown or the production cost breakdown structure in product profitability analysis. 

UCB Terminology and Concepts 

You may be familiar with an already existing solution called the “cost component split”, and yes it’s comparable, but UCB offers a lot more. 

To make the new UCB solution more distinguishable from the existing cost component split, we introduced a couple of new terms to describe the key entities of the new breakdown.  

  • UCB method: A component breakdown method is defined by an ID and a method type, which can be either a cost breakdown or a quantity breakdown, and the related component structure.

  • Quantity breakdown structure: The quantity breakdown structure groups quantity components, for example, greenhouse gas (GHG) categories.

  • Cost breakdown structure: The cost breakdown structure groups cost breakdown components and is used to explain, for example, the origin of costs in decision-making.

  • Quantity breakdown component: A quantity breakdown component is an individual element of the quantity breakdown that defines the origin of the quantity in question. For example, downstream transportation or purchased goods and services are possible quantity breakdown components when determining greenhouse gas emission quantities.

  • Cost breakdown component: The cost breakdown component groups G/L accounts that are used to create a detailed analysis of specific expenses associated with a product to gain a more granular insight into resource allocation. Cost breakdown components can be, for example, raw materials or overhead costs.

For more information, see Universal Component Breakdown.

Scope Activation and Dependencies

In order to enable the cost component breakdown, you need to activate scope item 7NH (Product Cost Breakdown in Plan/Actual Value Flow) in combination with the following mandatory prerequisite scope items: 

  • Integrated Financial Planning (4RC) enables cost rate planning and the cost rate split.

  • Import Connection Setup with SAP Analytics Cloud (1YB) enables the integration of the cost rate breakdown with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. It is only required if you want to use the origin cost breakdown. 

For more information on scoping, see SAP Note 3544173.

SAP Standard Content  

You define the cost breakdown structure and their assigned cost components in your configuration environment via the Define Cost Breakdown Structures (ID: 500697) configuration activity. Then, the cost breakdown results are determined automatically through the process of material standard cost estimates and the costs posting from the manufacturing and selling process. 

The following types of cost breakdown structures are available: 

  • Origin Cost Breakdown (OB): It describes the cost breakdown from the point of view of the original costs (for example, material usage with origin group, energy usage, labor usage).

  • Production Cost Breakdown (PB): It describes the cost breakdown from the point of view of the manufacturing process (for example, material usage, internal and external activities).

The production cost breakdown (PB) is the main breakdown structure and is used as the default structure in reporting. The cost of goods sold (COGS) breakdown is based on structures PB and OB. 

Overview of the configuration activity Define Cost Breakdown Structures.

Example of a production cost breakdown structure (PB).

Example of an origin cost breakdown structure (OB).

For more information, see Configuration on the SAP Help Portal. 

Cost Breakdown Hierarchies

In the Manage Global Hierarchies app, you can define your own cost breakdown hierarchies which you can use in reporting. They're based on the configured cost breakdown structures. SAP delivers two default cost breakdown hierarchies:

  • Universal Origin Cost Breakdown Group (UOCB) based on the origin cost breakdown structure.
  • Universal Production Cost Breakdown Group (UPCB) based on the production cost breakdown structure.

 

Predelivered cost breakdown hierarchies in the Manage Global Hierarchies app.

Example of an origin cost breakdown hierarchy.

Cost breakdown hierarchies replace the old cost component group concept. You don't have to define them in your configuration environment any longer. Instead you can maintain them anytime as a business user. 

For more information, see Define Component Breakdown Hierarchies on the SAP Help Portal. 

In the second part of this blog, we will illustrate how UCB works in an end-to-end scenario, first in the plan value flow and then in the actual value flow: Universal Component Breakdown (UCB): Revolutionizing Product Cost Management and Transparency Pt. 2 

Related Information

For more information, check out the following pages: 

What’s New (release 2508)

Universal Component Breakdown (UCB) 

Display Cost Rates 

Monitor Material Prices 

Cost of Goods Manufactured - Review Booklet 

Product Profitability Review Booklet 

SAP Help Portal Documentation:

Universal Component Breakdown 

Cost Component Breakdown 

View Component Breakdown 

Importing Plan Cost Rates from SAP Analytics Cloud 

Configuration 

Define Component Breakdown Hierarchies

Monitor Material Prices 

Cost of Goods Manufactured - Review Booklet 

Product Profitability Review Booklet 

Display Cost Rates 

SAP Notes: 

3544173 - Universal Component Breakdown (UCB): Product Cost Breakdown (Scope Item 7NH) in S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition 

3616085 - Calculation of COGS fixed amounts in app Product Profitability Review Booklet (F8348) 

3408777 - Product-Related Greenhouse Gas Emission Quantities in Product Costing (Scope Item 6VN): FAQ 

Scope Item Descriptions: 

Product Cost Breakdown in Plan/Actual Value Flow (7NH)

entry.title: 1XF - Request For Price (Creating Price Request for Quotation in Multiple Suppliers)
entry.content:
Manage RFQs is choose in SAP Best Practices instead of Request for Quotation (ME41):

Manage RFQs app is recommended in SAP Best Practices over ME41, as it provides a modern Fiori-based interface, supports approval workflows, enables supplier collaboration, and aligns with digital procurement processes in SAP S/4HANA.

Limitations of AN in Fiori-based Manage RFQs:

Limitation

Explanation

No Output Management (BRF+)

AN is not pre-configured for output control using BRF+ (Business Rules Framework Plus), which is used in Fiori apps for sending RFQs to suppliers.

No Flexible Workflow Support

It lacks integration with Flexible Workflow, which is essential for approval processes in Fiori apps.

Not Aligned with CDS Views

The Manage RFQs app uses CDS views and OData services that expect a different document type configuration (e.g., ZNB, ZFO) aligned with Fiori scenarios.

Missing Form Templates

The AN document type doesn’t come with pre-assigned Adobe forms/templates for smart forms used in Fiori-based communications.

  1. To open the app, select the Manage RFQs tile.

 

       2. Choose to create.

  1. Select Request for Quotation.

There are two types of creations:

  1. Ext. Sourcing Req (Doc. Type RE)
  2. Request for Quotation (Doc. Type RQ)

Request for Quotation:

  • A formal invitation to suppliers to submit quotations for the supply of goods or services.
  • You create it manually or based on a Purchase Requisition (PR).

Use Case:

  • When you want to collect competitive offers from vendors before placing a Purchase Order.

Ext. Sourcing Req:

  • These are requests already being processed through external sourcing platforms or tools like SAP Ariba, or via email.
  • The sourcing need may come from external systems or may be pushed outside the internal sourcing process.

Used when:

  • You are managing or tracking RFQs that are handled through external systems, like Ariba Network or another supplier portal.
  • The sourcing request has left the internal boundary and is in supplier hands or external tools.

Here, when I choose "Request for Quotation", the system defaults triggers the document type "RQ"

  1. Maintain the RFQ Description.

  1. To select the quotation deadline date, open the date picker and maintain the date.

  1. In the Organization section, enter the Purchasing Group, Purchasing Organization, and Company Code, then press Enter.

  1. To search for the follow-on doc. type, open the input help.

  1. In the search field, enter MK and click on GO.

  1. Select document type MK.

  1. To select a start date from when the RFQ will be valid, open the date picker and select the Start date 16/06/2025.

  1. To select an end date at which the RFQ will no longer be valid, open the date picker and Select End date 07/31/2025.

  1. Choose Delivery and Payment Terms Tab.

  1. In the Target Value field, enter 10,000 and Currency field, enter USD and click on Enter.

  1. Choose Items Tab.

  1. Choose to create.

  1. In the Material field, enter 20625 and press Enter.

  1. In the Plant field, enter US01 and press Enter.

  1. In the Requested Quantity field, enter 100 and press Enter.

  1. Choose Bidders Tab.

  1. To add one or more bidders, choose Create.

  1. In the Supplier field, enter 40018 and press Enter.

  1. To add a second supplier, choose Create.

  1. In the Supplier field, enter 40038 and press Enter.

  1. Choose Create.

  1. RFQ was created and Choose Output Details Tab.

  1. Output was triggered.

  1. To view the document in Print form, click on Display Document Action tab as show.

  1. The system will display the Print preview document.

  1. When a new Request for Quotation (RFQ) is created, the system initially displays the status as "In Preparation".

Click on Publish button.

  1. Once the "Publish" button is clicked, the RFQ is submitted for automatic approval, and the status updates to "In Approval".

entry.title: Universal Component Breakdown (UCB): Revolutionizing Product Cost Management and Transparency Pt. 2
entry.content:
Co-authored by @EvaWang and Jessica Dewald

This is the second part of the UCB blog series. If you're new to the UCB solution, you might want to read the introduction blog first: Universal Component Breakdown (UCB): Revolutionizing Product Cost Management and Transparency Pt. 1 

Welcome back and let's get right into our first example scenario.

 

UCB Process Example: Plan Value Flow 

Imagine you’re a cost accountant at an e-bike company and you just received a critical task to complete product cost planning for your plant 1710 and make it ready for actual production execution and product cost controlling. This quarter, your company wants to achieve an increased margin for the flagship products to stay competitive. You use UCB to identify the cost drivers that can help improve cost efficiency. 

Here's how you tackle it step by step using UCB in a plan value flow: 

Start with Financial Planning in SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) and Plan Data Import 

This step is triggered by the financial planning in your company, product cost planning is part of the yearly financial planning. 

Once that’s done, you integrate the financial planning data, especially plan cost rates and the cost rates split, directly into the SAP Cloud ERP system - ensuring everything is aligned and ready for the follow-up processes. 

Check Plan Cost Rates 

You can now display the cost breakdown result of a cost rate in your system:

Display Cost Rates app 

You use the Display Cost Rates app to display the different breakdown approaches in parallel. The origin cost breakdown shows the cost rate’s split into its original cost factors. You may already know this concept from the primary cost component split.  

Comparison by period in table view and bar chart view in the Display Cost Rates app.

Pie chart view of an origin cost breakdown in the Display Cost Rates app.

Manage Cost Rates Plan app

In the Manage Cost Rates – Plan app, you review all planned activity cost rates, including both fixed and variable portions. You want to find out more about the original cost factors behind each rate, using the origin cost component breakdown structure to understand what’s driving your costs. 

Production and origin cost breakdown in the Manage Cost Rates – Plan app.

Create Standard Cost Estimates and Release Material Prices 

With your cost rates in place, you run scheduled jobs to calculate material standard cost estimates. You determine the cost component breakdown and release the material prices with full transparency into each component. 

Monitor Material Prices with Component Breakdown 

Now it’s time to validate your work. Open the Monitor Material Prices app and confirm that all material prices are available. Then, you zoom in on the finished materials to check the planned cost component ratios. Everything looks good, each cost component is accounted for, and the percentages align with your margin goals. 

Monitor Material Prices App 

The Monitor Material Prices app provides the material price related cost breakdown based on the standard cost calculation. Just like in the cost rate split analysis, you can analyze material prices based on origin cost breakdown to see the original cost factor and cost drivers at component level. 

Cost component breakdown displayed in table, pie and bar chart view in the Monitor Material Prices app.

Identify Cost Drivers for Future Efficiency 

With the groundwork laid, you have set-up your product cost standard costs and now you shift your focus to strategic analysis based on the actual business execution.

Your focus would be identifying the cost drivers that could help improve efficiency next quarter and into next year. Whether it's optimizing raw material usage, reducing overhead, or streamlining production activities, you’re now equipped with the data to make informed decisions. 

Now we’re ready to get going with the actual value flow based on the most straight forward processes with make-to-stock in-house production and sell-from-stock as an example.

 

UCB Process Example Part 2: Actual Value Flow - In-House Production Business with Make-to-Stock (MTO) and Sales Processes 

MTO production process overview.

 

Using UCB to Uncover Cost Drivers and Boost Product Margins 

You’re a cost accountant and an expert for the actual value flow of your plant’s operations. Products are manufactured using a make-to-stock approach and sold directly to customers. But now, it’s time to go beyond production and sales - you need to analyze the production costs, product profitability, identify cost drivers, and take action to improve margins. Here’s how you do it using the product cost breakdown based on UCB.  

Run In-House Production and Sales Processes

Your plant operates on a make-to-stock model. You produce the goods, complete the required business steps like material staging and activity confirmation, finish the product manufacturing activities, and then deliver the products to customers. With that, the control over the goods is shifted to your customer and you’re ready to dive into the financials. 

First of all, let's look at how the cost component breakdown is reflected on journal entry level. The cost component breakdown is available for every single document posting of production activity confirmation, raw material consumption on production order, production overhead posting, and material goods movement journal entry documents, including the outbound delivery goods issue for the COGS breakdown. 

Manage Journal Entries (New Version) App 

In the Manage Journal Entries app, for example, you can access cost component breakdowns for journal entries to analyze posting confirmations, material consumption, and goods receipts of production orders: 

Origin cost breakdown in the Manage Journal Entries (New Version) app.

Analyze COGS Breakdown after Make-to-Stock Process is Finished  

To get a clearer picture, you open the Costs of Goods Manufactured Review Booklet. You can view the actual COGM values or compare current costs with previous periods and spot red flags in both raw material and production cost components. 

Cost of Goods Manufactured (COGM) Review Booklet 

The COGM Review Booklet provides comprehensive analytics reports for the cost of goods manufactured after production costs have been posted from production activities and goods movements etc. You can now view and analysis the COGM in a hierarchical view based on the production cost component hierarchy or original cost component hierarchy. It shows costs at each component level as well as the subtotal costs at hierarchy node level, for example, total overhead costs or total material costs. 

 Identifying the Root Cause 

You drill down into the COGM component breakdown by order, cost origin or accounts etc. The review booklet provides flexibility to make the needful dimension available in the reporting based on your own needs. 

Period comparison in the COGM Review Booklet.

Run Sell-from-Stock and Analyze COGS Posting and COGS Breakdown  

In our example, an outbound delivery is completed for the sales order 488476, that is, the flagship product bike MZ-FG-M500 is delivered from warehouse to customer 10100001. With that, the accounting document 4900000078 is posted, which credits inventory and debits COGS, the latter represents the expense associated with the sold product MZ-FG-M500. 

COGS line items in the Manage Journal Entries app.

In the COGS line item (4900000078/000002), you can view the cost components that comprise the total COGS amount and its fixed and variable parts in both company code currency and group currency. 

The following screen shows the cost breakdown components using the origin cost breakdown (method CBOB): 

Origin cost breakdown in the line item view of the Manage Journal Entries app.

You can also switch to the production cost breakdown method CBPB. 

Production cost breakdown in the COGM Review Booklet.

Review Product Performance in Product Profitability Review Booklet

Go to the Product Profitability Review Booklet and open the Margin View to assess how your products are performing during this period. One of the products sold exceeds  expectations with a 35% margin. But the other one is underperforming at just 15%, which is well below the target. You know it’s time to investigate further. 

Product Profitability Review Booklet 

With the Product Profitability Review Booklet, you can access the total contribution margin view. Additionally, the COGS breakdown view can help you to understand your total cost of goods sold either according to the production cost breakdown or to illustrate the original cost factors. Furthermore, fixed and variable costs split are also supported in the end-to-end process. 

Year-to-date margin view in the Product Profitability Review Booklet.

You can display the COGS breakdown with the production cost breakdown structure in a hierarchical view: 

Year-to-date COGS breakdown on the basis of the production cost breakdown in the Product Profitability Review Booklet.The second option lets you display the COGS breakdown based on the origin cost breakdown in a hierarchical view, enabling you to analyze the original cost factors, such as energy or water: Year-to-date COGS breakdown on the basis of the origin cost breakdown in the Product Profitability Review Booklet.

The third option lets you display the COGS breakdown component by product sold:  

Year-to-date COGS breakdown by cost breakdown component "Product Sold" in the Product Profitability Review Booklet.

This option lets you display the COGS breakdown related to the product sold: 

Year-to-date COGS breakdown related to the product sold.

These are just a few examples to demonstrate the flexibility you have with the drill-down options and filters available in review booklets.

Let’s summarize what we learned: By leveraging UCB with the help of the new review booklet capabilities, you’re not just tracking costs, you’re uncovering insights that drive necessary decisions. You’re helping your organization by providing needful insights to stay competitive, efficient, and profitable.

What's the relationship between the existing cost component split solution (CCS) and UCB?

At the moment, you can still use the existing cost component split solution (based on scope item BEG) and UCB (based on scope item 7NH) in parallel. We recommend you use the existing solution CCS with scope item BEG for go-live purposes until the scope of UCB reaches the intended coverage. 

For more information about scoping, see SAP Note 3544173 - Universal Component Breakdown (UCB): Product Cost Breakdown (Scope Item 7NH) in SAP Cloud ERP.

We know there’s still a lot to unpack with this new solution and there’s more to come on the SAP Community soon. Feel free to post your comments and questions below. We’re looking forward to hearing from you.

 

Related Information

For more information, check out the following pages: 

What’s New (release 2508)

Universal Component Breakdown (UCB) 

Display Cost Rates 

Monitor Material Prices 

Cost of Goods Manufactured - Review Booklet 

Product Profitability Review Booklet 

SAP Help Portal Documentation:

Universal Component Breakdown 

Cost Component Breakdown 

View Component Breakdown 

Importing Plan Cost Rates from SAP Analytics Cloud 

Configuration 

Define Component Breakdown Hierarchies

Monitor Material Prices 

Cost of Goods Manufactured - Review Booklet 

Product Profitability Review Booklet 

Display Cost Rates 

SAP Notes: 

3544173 - Universal Component Breakdown (UCB): Product Cost Breakdown (Scope Item 7NH) in S/4 HANA Cloud Public Edition 

3616085 - Calculation of COGS fixed amounts in app Product Profitability Review Booklet (F8348) 

3408777 - Product-Related Greenhouse Gas Emission Quantities in Product Costing (Scope Item 6VN): FAQ 

Scope Item Descriptions: 

Product Cost Breakdown in Plan/Actual Value Flow (7NH) 

Integrated Financial Planning (4RC) 

Import Connection Setup with SAP Analytics Cloud (1YB) 

Product-Related Carbon Emission Quantities (6VN)

entry.title: Product Hierarchy in Sales Processing - Typical Use Cases
entry.content:
In this blog,  the following 4 typical Product Hierarchy use cases in sales processing  will be shared.

  • Product Hierarchy for Sales Analytics 
  • Product Hierarchy for Pricing 
  • Product Hierarchy for Material Listing & Exclusion
  • Product Hierarchy for Sales Contract Price Agreement 

Use case 1 - Product Hierarchy for Sales Analytics. 

Insales Web Dynpro apps, when you select product for multi-dimensional analysis, you could easily enable and select a product hierarchy.  All valid product hierarchies could be selected for analytic display.

So that your data will be displayed in a structured format and easily aggregate or drill down KPIs by collapse or expand the product hierarchy or product hierarchy nodes.

Please note,  product hierarchy can only be supported in the following sales Web Dynpro apps. 

  •  Incoming Sales Orders - Flexible Analysis
  •  Sales Volume – Flexible Analysis
  • Customer Return - Flexible Analysis
  • Sales Quotation - Flexible Analysis

Use Case 2 - Product Hierarchy for Pricing 

Prerequistes：To make sure unique product hierarchy could be determined in sales processing, the product hierarchy must be assigned to a sales distribution chain (sales Organization + Distribution Chain). The screenshot shows some examples.

Product hierarchy determination in sales documents

When a sales order is created, the product hierarchy of the product and the related condition type will be automatically determined.  So far the determined product hierarchy and product parent node are only visible in Web GUI app under Sales B section.   The predefined product hierarchy condition type is DPH1. And it could be checked in both Fiori app and Web GUI app.

The following screenshot shows the product Hierarchy condition type DPH1 in Manage Sales Order - Version 2. 

Once the product hierarchy and hierarch nodes are determined in sales documents items, they will be copied to the succeeding documents to ensure consistent prices.

 

For example, if product hierarchy has been determined in sales quotation. When a sales order is created with reference to the sales quotation, the same product hierarchy will be copied. Therefore, if the product hierarchy master data is changed between sales quotation and sales order creation, the product hierarchy in sales order will not be redetermined.

Customizing Option

By default, the product hierarchy is determined based on sales order pricing date. This could be changed to Document Creation Date in SSCUI 107215. The corresponding screenshots are attached below:

 

 Use Case 3 - Product Hierarchy for Material Listing & Exclusion

Material listing exclusion is a feature to restrict sales of particular materials (products) in certain sales document(s) (Help portal for material listing & Exclusion) If a material has been excluded,  an error message will pop up showing this product cannot be sold in this sales order. 

 

 

Since 2022, the product hierarchy has been enabled for material listing &Exclusion. So you could easily allow or exclude the sales of a group of products under specified product hierarchy node. 

 

Use Case 4 - Product Hierarchy for  Sales Contract Price Agreement 

In CE2502，a new item category VC03 has been released to support product hierarchy in sales value contract.  So you could set special price agreement for a group of products by specifying a product hierarchy and product hierarchy node in sales contract item. 

For example, a value contract is created with two items. 

  • Item 10 is based on a product hierarchy (SALES_PRODUCT _HIE), node (2025_S1) , with special price agreement 10% of discount.

 

  • Item 20 is based on a procuct (PRODUCT_C) with special price agreement 15% of discount.

The product hierarchy (SALES_PRODUCT _HIE) structure is attached below as a reference.

 

To apply the special price agreement from sales contract to a sales order

  • You could create a sales order first and later assign the sales contract to the sales order so that the special price agreement will apply.  You only need to enter the contract number, the items could be assigned automatically. For contract item auto assignment, please check this video:

 

Automatic Sales Contract Item Assignment to A Sales Order based on Product Hierarchy

 

  • You could also create a sales order with reference to a sales contract with product hierarchy. Please check the video below for the details.

 

Create Sales Order with Reference to Sales Contract with product Hierarchy

entry.title: 1XF - Request For Price (Creating Price Request for Quotation in Multiple Suppliers)
entry.content:
Creating Price Requests

Request for Price (1XF) is a standard SAP S/4HANA Best Practice scenario used in the Materials Management (MM) module. It enables the purchasing department to request pricing information from suppliers before initiating the procurement process.

Purpose:

This process is used to collect price quotations from multiple suppliers for specific materials or services, helping the organization to:

  • Understand current market pricing
  • Compare offers from suppliers
  • Make informed purchasing decisions
  • Proceed to purchase only after evaluating competitive prices

Key Process Steps:

  1. Create RFQ (Request for Quotation) in the system
  2. Send RFQ to be selected suppliers
  3. Receive and record supplier quotations
  4. Evaluate and compare quotations
  5. Create a follow-on Purchase Order for the selected supplier.

Manage RFQs is choose in SAP Best Practices instead of Request for Quotation (ME41):

Manage RFQs app is recommended in SAP Best Practices over ME41, as it provides a modern Fiori-based interface, supports approval workflows, enables supplier collaboration, and aligns with digital procurement processes in SAP S/4HANA.

Limitations of AN in Fiori-based Manage RFQs:

Limitation

Explanation

No Output Management (BRF+)

AN is not pre-configured for output control using BRF+ (Business Rules Framework Plus), which is used in Fiori apps for sending RFQs to suppliers.

No Flexible Workflow Support

It lacks integration with Flexible Workflow, which is essential for approval processes in Fiori apps.

Not Aligned with CDS Views

The Manage RFQs app uses CDS views and OData services that expect a different document type configuration (e.g., ZNB, ZFO) aligned with Fiori scenarios.

Missing Form Templates

The AN document type doesn’t come with pre-assigned Adobe forms/templates for smart forms used in Fiori-based communications.

1. To open the app, select the Manage RFQs tile.

2. Choose to create.

3. Select Request for Quotation.

There are two types of creations:

  1. Ext. Sourcing Req (Doc. Type RE)
  2. Request for Quotation (Doc. Type RQ)

Request for Quotation:

  • A formal invitation to suppliers to submit quotations for the supply of goods or services.
  • You create it manually or based on a Purchase Requisition (PR).

Use Case:

  • When you want to collect competitive offers from vendors before placing a Purchase Order.

Ext. Sourcing Req:

  • These are requests already being processed through external sourcing platforms or tools like SAP Ariba, or via email.
  • The sourcing need may come from external systems or may be pushed outside the internal sourcing process.

Used when:

  • You are managing or tracking RFQs that are handled through external systems, like Ariba Network or another supplier portal.
  • The sourcing request has left the internal boundary and is in supplier hands or external tools.

Here, when I choose "Request for Quotation", the system defaults triggers the document type "RQ"

4. Maintain the RFQ Description.

5. To select the quotation deadline date, open the date picker and maintain the date.

6. In the Organization section, enter the Purchasing Group, Purchasing Organization, and Company Code, then press Enter.

7. To search for the follow-on doc. type, open the input help.

8. In the search field, enter MK and click on GO.

9. Select document type MK.

10. To select a start date from when the RFQ will be valid, open the date picker and select the Start date 16/06/2025.

11. To select an end date at which the RFQ will no longer be valid, open the date picker and Select End date 07/31/2025.

12. Choose Delivery and Payment Terms Tab.

13. In the Target Value field, enter 10,000 and Currency field, enter USD and click on Enter.

14. Choose Items Tab.

15. Choose to create.

16. In the Material field, enter 20625 and press Enter.

17. In the Plant field, enter US01 and press Enter.

18. In the Requested Quantity field, enter 100 and press Enter.

19. Choose Bidders Tab.

20. To add one or more bidders, choose Create.

21. In the Supplier field, enter 40018 and press Enter.

22. To add a second supplier, choose Create.

23. In the Supplier field, enter 40038 and press Enter.

24. Choose Create.

25. RFQ was created and Choose Output Details Tab.

26. Output was triggered.

27. To view the document in Print form, click on Display Document Action tab as show.

28. The system will display the Print preview document.

29. When a new Request for Quotation (RFQ) is created, the system initially displays the status as "In Preparation".

Click on Publish button.

31. Once the "Publish" button is clicked, the RFQ is submitted for automatic approval, and the status updates to "In Approval".

entry.title: Smooth Transition for your SAP PaPM Cloud UM containers with SAP Cloud Transport Management service
entry.content:
This blogpost walks you through how to use SAP Cloud Transport Management with the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud - Universal Model (SAP PaPM Cloud UM) in Manage Containers.

Why SAP Cloud Transport Management?

Pairing SAP Cloud Transport Management with SAP PaPM Cloud UM gives content managers a new dimension of flexibility. Instead of relying solely on the Manage Containers application, SAP Cloud Transport Management provides a more efficient, controlled, and secure approach to managing transports across tenants.

To dive deeper into what SAP Cloud Transport Management is and how it works, you can explore the SAP Cloud Transport Management documentation.

What Admins and Content Managers Need to Know

These are several important points to keep in mind:

  1. SAP Cloud Transport Management will not replace Manage Containers – Think of it as an additional transport option. You can choose the one that best fits your use case.
  2. SAP Cloud Transport Management is not bundled with SAP PaPM Cloud UM – It’s a separate license, so make sure to evaluate the entitlements before planning your transport strategy.
  3. One subscription can serve multiple subaccounts – A single SAP Cloud Transport Management subscription can be configured and linked to multiple SAP PaPM subaccounts.

In this example, I will create a three-node landscape and set up routes similar to what is commonly used in a real-world business scenario. It is common to work with at least three tenants for modeling purposes: Development, where ideas are first modeled, Quality Assurance (QA) to validate, and Production for business use. 

In Manage Containers, you will find the Release for Transport button. But before using it, SAP Cloud Transport Management must be properly configured in your SAP BTP subaccount. For step-by-step instructions and setup details, you can refer to our Admin Guide – SAP Cloud Transport Management.

There are four types of URL destinations available, and you can quickly copy them in the Administration Guide - URL.

Option 1: URL for Importing an Environment via Manage Containers

Option 2: URL for Uploading and/or Restoring Archived Demo Data via Manage Archives

Note: The environment should be activated to successfully restore demo data.

 

As I've mentioned above, I have created a three-node landscape and set up routes in SAP Cloud Transport Management.

  • The Development node serves solely as a virtual node and placeholder before a content transition to the succeeding node which in this case is the Quality Assurance (QA) node.
  • The Quality Assurance (QA) node uses an Activate URL (https://<PaPMServiceKey.url>/ace/sap/ace/tms/activate) which allows you to upload a container then import and activate the environment before moving to the Production node.
  • The Production node uses the Import URL (https://<PaPMServiceKey.url>/ace/sap/ace/tms/import) which allows you to upload a container and import it without activating the environment.

To create a transport object for transport, perform the following steps:

  1. Go to the Administration application group and choose the Manage Containers application.
  2. Select the desired container and choose Release for Transport.
  3. Select the transport node to be released and choose Release to Transport.
  4. The Transport Request number will be displayed on the screen.

 

In SAP Cloud Transport Management, the Transport Request will reflect allowing you to seamlessly move the container in the created transport nodes and routes.

  1. Go to SAP Cloud Transport Management application and choose Landscape Visualization.
  2. Choose the Development node and select Import Queue.
  3. Select the Transport Request and choose Import Selected.

 

After you have successfully imported the Transport Request to the Quality Assurance (QA) node, you may now start importing this container to the set destination tenant of this node by following the steps above, but this time in the Quality Assurance (QA) node.

 

In the SAP PaPM Cloud UM – Quality Assurance (QA) tenant, you can view the uploaded container in the Manage Containers and see it successfully imported and activated in Manage Environments application.

 

Going back to SAP Cloud Transport Management, the Transport Request has been successfully transitioned to the Production node and is ready to be imported to the set destination.

 

In the SAP PaPM Cloud UM – Production tenant, you can view the uploaded container in the Manage Containers application and see it successfully imported in Manage Environments application. 

 

Now that you understand how to use SAP Cloud Transport Management service to transition your environment across SAP PaPM Cloud UM tenants, you can confidently streamline your transport process with improved control, traceability, and efficiency. This ensures that your models move seamlessly and securely from Development to Production.

 

Happy transporting! 🚀

Stay tuned for more updates and enhancements!

entry.title: Introduction to Service Request Management with SAP Enterprise Service Management - Tips & Tricks
entry.content:
SAP Enterprise Service Management (ESM) is about systematically optimizing service processes across the enterprise – from HR and Finance to Facilities – with the goal of increasing efficiency, standardization, and user satisfaction. 

In this blog, you’ll learn how Case Management and Service Request Management are applied in practice, which configuration options exist, and how to define the right strategy for your organization. 

Case Management – Flexible and Versatile 

Case Management forms the foundation for every service process. Requests, incidents, or issues are captured quickly, without the need for standardized forms or complex workflows. 

Configuration Options and Practical Benefits: 

  • Single Case Type often sufficient: One Case Type can cover many different scenarios. 
  • No forms or case flows required: Information is captured via free-text or basic standard fields. 
  • Flexibility for unique cases: Perfect for rare, unpredictable, or complex requests that don’t require a structured process. 

Practical Tip: Case Management allows organizations to capture and document all types of requests – even the unexpected ones – while providing valuable insights into which processes could be standardized or automated. 

Service Request Management – Structured and Standardized 

When processes occur frequently and are well-defined, Service Request Management is the right choice. Here, the focus is on structured information collection and guided process execution. 

Configuration Options: 

Forms for structured information gathering: 

  • Multiple forms can be linked to a single Case Type. 
  • Forms can be dynamically controlled based on category, priority, or other parameters. 

Case Flow for process guidance: 

  • Guides agents step by step through the process. 
  • Clearly defines responsibilities, tasks, and priorities. 
  • Approvals can be integrated directly into the workflow. 

Practical Tip: Combining forms and case flows ensures that all necessary information is collected and processed systematically, no matter how complex the request. 

Levels of Service Request Management 

Basic Service Request Management: 

  • Structured data collection via forms 
  • Guided workflows through Case Flow 
  • Immediate benefits: saves time, reduces errors, increases transparency 
  • Examples: approvals, HR requests, material orders 

Advanced Service Request Management

  • Automation and integration with other enterprise systems 
  • Handles complex, multi-step processes: leave requests, onboarding, cross-department approvals 
  • Scalable for high-volume processes with multiple stakeholders 

Practical Tip: Advanced Service Request Management is ideal when processes are frequent and automation provides real value. 

Finding the Optimal Mix 

  • Case Management remains the flexible foundation for rare or individual requests. 
  • Service Request Management complements Case Management for standardized, repeatable processes. 
  • Prioritization: Analyze processes based on volume, complexity, and potential for optimization before introducing automation. 

Practical Tip: A balanced mix ensures that all requests are handled efficiently – from ad-hoc cases to high-volume service requests. 

Conclusion 

SAP Enterprise Service Management delivers its full potential when organizations: 

  • Use Case Management as a flexible, transparent, and adaptive foundation 
  • Apply Service Request Management selectively, with forms and case flows ensuring structured, standardized processes 
  • Prioritize and scale automation where it provides true value 

The result is a service delivery ecosystem that optimally combines flexibility, efficiency, and user satisfaction across the enterprise.

entry.title: Custom Business Configurations (F4579): Controlling the visibility of BC Objects using authorization
entry.content:
Introduction

The Custom Business Configurations (CUBCO) app serves as an entry point to the Business Configuration Maintenance Object provided by custom applications or partners.
Depending on the respective role the user should only be able to edit certain business configurations.

This blog is relevant for

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition  
  • SAP BTP ABAP environment  

Further reading:

  • Related blog posts
  • Learn how you can use ABAP technology to develop innovative applications and business solutions across SAP’s portfolio on SAP Learning Site.

Basic Concept

An OData V4 service is assigned to each business configuration object (SMBC). The corresponding service binding is based on a RAP BO.
The list of available business configuration objects in the CUBCO app is restricted to those where the user has the start authorization for the service binding (authorization object S_START,  see access control object I_SMBC_CONFIGURATION_TP).  The application-specific authorizations are not checked until an SMBC object has been selected. That is, authorization control implemented in the RAP BO. Normally, the authorization object S_TABU_NAM is used, but you can also use any other authorization object.

Therefore, you can create business roles in which only a subset of all business configuration objects can be used.

SAP BTP ABAP environment, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

IAM apps are the smallest building block for creating business roles. For a business configuration object, you assign the OData service binding and the application relevant authorization objects to it. You then create a business catalog to collect IAM apps and finally assign business catalogs to business roles.

Example:
You have four SMBC objects A, B, C, D in the system and a different OData service binding for each SMBC object. The authorization object S_TABU_NAM is used in all RAP BOs. You create four IAM apps A, B, C, D, each containing the OData service of a different SMBC object and the authorization object S_TABU_NAM. You create a business catalog BC1 that contains the IAM apps A, B, and a business catalog BC2 that contains the IAM apps B, C, D.

You assign a business role containing the business catalog BC1 to a user. This user can work with the SMBC objects A, B. The user cannot see or edit the SMBC objects C and D.
You assign a business role containing the business catalog BC2 to a user. This user can work with the SMBC objects B, C, D. The user cannot see or work with the SMBC object A.

SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition

IAM apps are not available. You add the application relevant authorization objects to the authorization default of the OData service assigned to the SMBC object. In the PFCG role you then add the authorization default.

Example:
You have four SMBC objects A, B, C, D in the system and a different OData service binding for each SMBC object. You assign a PFCG role containing the authorization default for the OData services of SMBC objects A, B to a user. This user can work with the SMBC objects A, B. The user cannot see or edit the SMBC objects C and D.

Note that roles that contain the Custom Business Configurations Fiori app do not automatically derive the required authorization for the SMBC objects. You need to add the authorization default of the OData service manually.

entry.title: Re: Update new pricing after changing pricing condition r...
entry.content:
When you manually perform “Update Pricing = G” in VA02, it essentially re-triggers the entire pricing determination process for the item, allowing all conditions (including your newly added one) to be evaluated, access sequences to run, and values to be calculated.

However, directly simulating this “Update Pricing = G” functionality within USEREXIT_XKOMV_BEWERTEN_END is generally not advisable or straightforward. This user exit is called during the pricing process, and attempting to re-trigger the entire pricing from within it can lead to infinite loops or unpredictable results.

For conditions you insert directly into XKOMV within USEREXIT_XKOMV_BEWERTEN_END, the expectation is that you will also provide the logic to calculate and populate its values (KBETR - rate, KWERT - value, KPEIN - price unit, KMEIN - unit, etc.) at that same point. The standard pricing engine doesn’t automatically re-evaluate access sequences for conditions manually added late in the process.

Therefore, the recommended approach is to include your specific logic for determining the value of your new pricing condition within the USEREXIT_XKOMV_BEWERTEN_END user exit, immediately after you insert it into XKOMV. You would read any necessary data from KOMK, KOMP, or other XKOMV entries and then set the relevant value fields for your newly inserted condition.

entry.title: 🇮🇳 SAP Build: Create Event-Based Processes (Bengaluru, India)
entry.content:
This is the all-new SAP CodeJam for SAP Build low-code/no-code tooling that focuses on giving you hands-on experience for building event-triggered processes with SAP Build Process Automation.

 

You will build an event-based scenario that lets users create S/4HANA business partners, setting off a process where:
  1. An employee approves the creation of a site access badge.
  2. A second employee, determined based on the details of the business partner, may also need to approve the badge.
  3. The process calls an external, 3rd-party badge system and waits to be called back.
  4. A user creates the badge and the badge system calls back the process instance.
  5. A notification with the badge ID is sent.

 

The scenario is built in 2 halves:

 

SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh: You will learn about events, CloudEvents, events in the SAP landscape, the process for publishing and subscribing to events, and your way around SAP Integration Suite, advanced event mesh. Then, you will create a REST Delivery Point in advanced event mesh to forward events to your SAP Build on your SAP BTP trial account.
 
SAP Build Process Automation: You will create a process from scratch to handle the issuance of site access badges. You will learn the basics of SAP Build Process Automation (projects, triggers, conditions, creating instances, monitoring, and the Inbox), and also use some of the more recent or advanced features (event triggers, form events, waiting for a API callback).
 
Prerequisites
  • Bring your own laptop with power adapter and have a supported Web browser such as Google Chrome or Firefox installed on your laptop.
  • It can be helpful to bring a tablet or second laptop, if you have.
  • Complete these prerequisites and the required reading BEFORE you come: 
    • Introduction to the CodeJam
    • Prerequisites
    • Required reading:
      • 1 - Exploring Events and More in the SAP Business Accelerator Hub
      • 2 - Why Event-Driven Architectures?

Location and Date

This is an in-person event only (not virtual) and is planned for Wednesday, December 10th, 2025 from 10:30 - 16:00 local time in Bengaluru, India. The language of the event and the content will be English. 

Event Address: Bosch EC3 (360° Business Park), Electronic City Phase I, Doddathoguru, Bengaluru, Karnataka, India

Google maps location: https://maps.app.goo.gl/nFkWrsEptwqE3ExL7

  • The instructors are SAP Developer Advocates  @ajay_soreng  and @Rekha_DR 
  • Thank you Robert Bosch for hosting this event.

Please note that spaces are limited! We can only accommodate 35 attendees. If you want to attend, register by clicking the Yes button in the Will you be attending? section above to the right. About two weeks before the event, you will be asked to confirm your attendance via email.

entry.title: Re: Message no. VL171
entry.content:
I encountered the same issue, and the root cause was that I attempted to post a Goods Issue directly from a Sales Order item while the inspection lot trigger for outbound delivery was active.

The problem occurs due to a quality block when you try to post the goods issue without completing a positive usage decision. I resolved this by configuring a Quality Info Record (QV51) for the customer to allow inspection “After Delivery.” With this setup, the error no longer appeared.

Additionally, it is also possible to follow the standard process for this inspection scenario:
Create the delivery → Record inspection results and make a positive usage decision → Post the Goods Issue.

entry.title: Re: Display PDF document as RAP Odata V4 Web API output
entry.content:
I would like to understand why you are trying to create a new service, when a standard service is already available: https://api.sap.com/api/API_CV_ATTACHMENT_SRV/overview

Your custom service should only expose the attachment keys, and then whoever needs to read the attachment, may use the above service to read attachment contents. You may read the attachment keys using:

CL_ATTACHMENT_SERVICE_API=>GET_INSTANCE( )->IF_ATTACHMENT_SERVICE_API~GET_LIST_OF_ATTACHMENTS

entry.title: Re: The Power of One: How Unified SAP Joule Boosts AI Adoption (a technical sight)
entry.content:
Hi @normann 

Below the fragment we got as a response from SAP on this with puts a HUGE limitation on using 3rd party IDP as UUID source. The suggested approach to make sure the user is "created first" by the Entra Synch is very complex to achieve. I just expect some option to limit the writeback or some other alternative. Otherwise the scenario to use 3rd party UUID in only something SAP writes in a nice architecture diagram and not something that can be actually achieved.

"....

  • The Global User ID is designed to be a stable and unique technical identifier across connected systems. In the default SuccessFactors–IAS integration, IAS generates this ID and writes it back to SuccessFactors (see SAP Note 0003530083).

  • In hybrid landscapes, it is technically possible to overwrite the Global User ID in SuccessFactors via IPS mappings, but this is not the recommended approach, as the identifier is expected to remain consistent once assigned.

  • The recommended best practice is to configure the leading system (in your case, Entra ID) to provision the Global User ID into IAS. IAS then becomes the central broker and propagates the value to SuccessFactors, Ariba, S/4HANA, and other connected solutions. This avoids the need for overwrites and ensures consistency from the start.

.....

....in the standard SuccessFactors–IAS integration, the Global User ID is written back from IAS into SuccessFactors as part of the delivered flow. This is not triggered by any custom job or transformation but is part of the standard integration design (see SAP Note 3530083).

Currently, there is no configuration option in SuccessFactors or IAS to disable this writeback. The UUID propagation is mandatory and not switchable.

To avoid IAS generating a random UUID that is then written back, the recommended best practice is to ensure that the Global User ID is already provisioned from your leading system (e.g., Entra ID) into IAS before the SuccessFactors–IAS synchronization runs. In this way, IAS will use the Entra-provisioned identifier instead of generating its own value.

If your requirement is to suppress the writeback entirely or to have a configuration “switch” to control this behavior, this goes beyond current product capabilities and would be considered a product enhancement..... "

entry.title: In ABAP Unit, failing to get the number of available workprocesses for pRFC
entry.content:
I'm trying to create a framework over pRFC (CALL FUNCTION ... IN BACKGROUND TASK ...)

I want to test the framework via ABAP Unit, in one of my tests I need to get the number of available workprocesses for pRFC to stress the framework.

There are two possibilities to get this number but both of them fail:

  1. Call SPBT_INITIALIZE to get the number and it works, but the code under test fails because it tries again to call SPBT_INITIALIZE, which is forbidden in the same internal session (exception PBT_ENV_ALREADY_INITIALIZED).
  2. Call SPBT_GET_CURR_RESOURCE_INFO, but the exception PBT_ENV_NOT_INITIALIZED_YET is raised because SPBT_INITIALIZE has not been called before.

Thanks.

Sandra

entry.title: Re: In ABAP Unit, failing to get the number of available workprocesses for pRFC
entry.content:
In ABAP Unit, call successively:

  • SPBT_INITIALIZE
  • SPBT_GET_CURR_RESOURCE_INFO to get the number of available workprocesses for pRFC

In your framework, call successively:

  • SPBT_INITIALIZE and ignore the exception PBT_ENV_ALREADY_INITIALIZED
  • SPBT_GET_CURR_RESOURCE_INFO to get the number of available workprocesses for pRFC

entry.title: Re: I am getting a blank page when I preview my RAP servi...
entry.content:
Before you do anything with security or anything else, please give the system some breathing/sleeping time.

This is utterly annoying, but we have faced this issue so many times in S/4 Public Cloud. There is some cache somewhere, invisible to us, that doesn't get updated/refreshed whenever a new binding/application is published and until that happens, the UCON error will continue to happen.

Unfortunately, requests to SAP to provide us a method to clear/reset the cache ourselves, was denied.

So, this what we do as workarounds:

  1. Add the CDS to an existing already published Service Definition. Since this is an existing service, the newly added CDS will be readily available via this service. We have a local/test Service Definition created in Dev system, exactly for this purpose.
  2. Wait for a few hours for the cache to be cleared (sometimes it takes a whole night) for your new service endpoint to work.

entry.title: How to update “Display-only” material master fields (Gross/Net Weight) via MM17 or IDoc in S/4HANA?
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I am working in S/4HANA and I have a scenario with material master fields MARA-BRGEW (Gross Weight) and MARA-NTGEW (Net Weight).

  • In MM02, these fields are set to Display only via field selection (OMS9/OMS2).

  • I want to update these fields via MM17 (mass maintenance) or MATMAS IDoc.

  • Currently, SAP blocks the change and returns MG140: “Field not ready for input”.

I understand that SAP marks these fields as non-dialog in the backend, so the “Display only” status does not allow updates through direct input or IDocs.

My question:
Is there a standard / S/4HANA-supported way to update these display-only fields programmatically (via IDoc, MM17, or API), without changing the MM02 screen status?

entry.title: Re: SAP DRC, Peppol / Error at PUSH operation HTTP respon...
entry.content:
Click on the 'Failed to push document'. The error details will be downloaded in a .txt file. It will give you details like error code and error message.

We faced a similar issue with the error - 'Server returned HTTP response code: 401 for URL: http://..................../pushrequest' & 'Header null - HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized'. 

The root cause was identified as a password change for the user configured in the 'Destinations' section of our subaccount. - Setting Up Connectivity | SAP Help Portal'

Below trouble shooting guides helped in resolving this issue:

Troubleshooting Malaysia eDocument integration with DRC Cloud edition | SAP Help Portal

3605221 - eDocument Stuck in "Acknowledged by Service" with HTTP 401 Error During PUSH Step - SAP for Me

3498170 - Troubleshooting guide: Electronic communication integration of SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition and SAP applications - SAP for Me

HI @AnnaLucini 

  • C_TS452
    This certification verifies that you possess the cores and core skills in the area of sourcing and procurement line of business area required of the consultant profile and proves that you have an overall understanding and in-depth skills to participate as a member of a project team with a focus on the planning and implementation phases in a mentored role.
    This certification is relevant for SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition and SAP S/4HANA on-premise.

  • C_S4CPR
    This certification verifies that you possess the fundamental knowledge required to explain and execute core implementation project tasks to deploy, adopt and extend SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as well as core knowledge in Sourcing & Procurement. It proves that the candidate has an overall understanding and in-depth technical skills to participate as a member of a SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition implementation project team with a focus on Sourcing & Procurement in a mentored role.
         Please cees our SAP CERTIFICATION C_S4CPR SAP Certified Associate - Implementation Consultant - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Sourcing and Procurement site for more details.

Margit

entry.title: Invitation to the SAP Community Stammtisch Berlin on the Eve of SAP TechEd 2025!
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community, dear friends and valued colleagues,

The SAP Community is finally reuniting at SAP TechEd in Berlin this year, and what better way to kick off the week, than getting together for a Stammtisch at one of Berlin’s breweries?

Whether you are from Berlin or traveling to Berlin for SAP TechEd – this evening is for you. 

When? Monday, November 3, 2025, from 6:30 PM

Where? Hofbräu Wirtshaus Berlin, Karl-Liebknecht-Str. 30, 10178 Berlin

 It is an open and informal networking event for everyone, organized by the SAP Community Group Berlin.

We look forward to a sociable evening with great conversations and hope many of you will take the time to stop by. You are welcome to stay the whole evening, or just stop by to say hi. 

This get-together is the perfect opportunity to:

  • Reconnect with old acquaintances: Meet up with friends and colleagues from the community

  • Make new contacts: Get to know other SAP experts and newcomers -no one should leave the event without speaking to at least two new people you have not met before 🙂
  • Conversations: This Stammtisch is all about the conversations, and the community getting together face-to-face again. Get the week started by discussing the latest SAP technology announcements, or keep it casual and catch up on everything that has happened since we last met (not necessarily technology related). 

To help us with the planning, we kindly ask you to confirm your attendance via the RSVP button of this event post.

Important Note: Please be aware that all attendees are responsible for their own food and drinks!

We can't wait to see you there!

Best regards, Your SAP Community Group Berlin Team

-----------------------------

Liebe SAP Community, liebe Freunde und geschätzte Kollegen,

die SAP Community kommt dieses Jahr endlich wieder zur SAP TechEd in Berlin zusammen! Und wie könnte man die Woche besser einläuten, als mit einem gemeinsamen Stammtisch in einem Berliner Brauhaus?

Egal, ob ihr aus Berlin kommt oder für die SAP TechEd anreist – dieser Abend ist für euch.

Wann: Montag, den 03. November 2025, ab 18:30 Uhr

Wo: Hofbräu Wirtshaus Berlin, Karl-Liebknecht-Str. 30, 10178 Berlin

Es handelt sich um ein offenes und ungezwungenes Networking-Event für alle, organisiert von der SAP Community Group Berlin.

Wir freuen uns auf einen geselligen Abend mit tollen Gesprächen und hoffen, dass viele von euch die Zeit finden, vorbeizuschauen. Ihr seid herzlich eingeladen, den ganzen Abend zu bleiben oder auch nur kurz auf ein "Hallo" hereinzukommen.

Dieses Treffen ist die perfekte Gelegenheit für:

  • Wiedersehen mit alten Bekannten: Trefft Freunde und Kollegen aus der Community.

  • Knüpfen neuer Kontakte: Lernt andere SAP-Experten und Neulinge kennen – niemand sollte den Abend beenden, ohne mit mindestens zwei neuen Personen gesprochen zu haben, die er oder sie vorher noch nicht kannte 🙂
  • Gespräche: Bei diesem Stammtisch dreht sich alles um den Austausch und das persönliche Wiedersehen der Community. Startet die Woche mit Diskussionen über die neuesten Ankündigungen zur SAP-Technologie oder haltet es ganz entspannt und tauscht euch darüber aus, was seit unserem letzten Treffen so alles passiert ist (nicht zwingend technologiebezogen).

Um uns die Planung zu erleichtern, bitten wir euch, eure Teilnahme über den RSVP-Button dieses Beitrags zu bestätigen.

Wichtiger Hinweis: Bitte beachtet, dass alle Teilnehmer für ihre Speisen und Getränke selbst aufkommen!

Wir können es kaum erwarten, euch zu sehen!

Viele Grüße, Euer Team der SAP Community Group Berlin

entry.title: BTP Trial Update: CF Runtime Availability
entry.content:
Dear SAP BTP trial community,

 
We always aimed to give users the most freedom and flexibility in the SAP BTP trial to ensure that everyone can test and explore our software or use it for learning purposes. For the next weeks, the SAP BTP trial will not be able to deliver this experience for new SAP BTP trial accounts as we have to prioritize the security and reliability of our SAP BTP trial system. We are experiencing an unusually high amount of misuse limiting the availability for all of our users. 
 
Therefore, we decided to temporarily reduce the offering for the SAP BTP Cloud Foundry runtime for new BTP Trial Accounts. You will still be able to build applications and preview them, but deployment in the SAP BTP Cloud Foundry runtime will not be possible for the next weeks. 
 
How can you still explore SAP BTP? 
  • All other services will remain available and can be explored on the SAP Discovery Center
  • Leverage our SAP Basic trial offerings 
  • As a partner: Refer to our newly released free TDD licenses
  • As a customer: Leverage the free tier offering as part of Pay-As-You-Go for SAP BTP available in the SAP Store
 

All updates will be posted in the SAP Community. 

If you have an existing account, you are not affected. 
 
See you soon, 
SAP BTP trial product team

entry.title: SAP GRC 2026 - Assurance & Compliance Solutions - New features
entry.content:
SAP GRC 2026 - Assurance & Compliance Solutions - New features

Organizations today face increasing regulatory demands and operational risks.
SAP continues to evolve its Assurance & Compliance solutions to help businesses stay ahead. Here’s a look at the latest enhancements designed to optimize user experience, streamline processes, and leverage AI for smarter compliance.

✅ SAP Business Integrity Screening
A) Fiori Apps for Detection Runs
Reimplemented using Fiori Elements for a modern, consistent user experience.
Key Benefit: Enhanced efficiency through streamlined interfaces and advanced filtering for precise detection runs.

B) Improved Performance for Managing Alerts App
Optimized for high-volume alert scenarios and large datasets.
Key Benefit: Increased responsiveness in high-demand environments.

✅ SAP Tax Compliance
A) Bulk Edit User Group Attributes
Edit multiple user groups and attributes in a single operation with flexible update options.
Key Benefit: Efficient, flexible bulk updates for better governance.

✅ SAP Audit Management
A) Import Master Data from PC/RM in Same System
Simplifies data management and integration without RFC setup.
Key Benefit: Reduces complexity and maintenance.

B) Consolidate Email Notifications for Multiple Actions
Groups related notifications for streamlined communication.
Key Benefit: Reduces email clutter and enhances focus.

C) Audit Coverage Overview Page
Provides a comprehensive visual view of audit coverage.
Key Benefit: Improves transparency and strategic planning.

D) Share Recommendations by Different Findings
Enables targeted recommendations and collaborative problem-solving.
Key Benefit: Enhances relevance and customization of audit feedback.

E) Integrate Audit Process with SAP Workflow
Track audits via Fiori apps and workflows.
Key Benefit: Streamlines processes and reduces manual tasks.

F) Enhanced Survey Capabilities
Supports more question types and score mapping.
Key Benefit: Improves flexibility and depth of audit surveys.

G) AI-Supported Audit Report Summary
Leverages AI to generate tailored audit summaries using prompts.
Key Benefit: Enhances report relevance and utility.

🌟 Why This Matters
These innovations empower compliance teams to:
Improve operational efficiency
Reduce manual effort
Gain actionable insights through AI
Ensure robust governance across processes

💬 What do you think about these new SAP Assurance & Compliance features?
Drop your thoughts in the comments or reach out if you’d like to explore these capabilities further.

entry.title: IAM for SAP Joule
entry.content:
🔐 IAM for SAP Joule: Building Secure, Scalable AI Experiences
As organizations embrace SAP Joule and SAP Business AI, Identity and Access Management (IAM) becomes the backbone of secure and seamless integration across business applications. Here’s what you need to know:

✅ Why IAM Matters for Joule
SAP Joule is more than a conversational AI—it connects processes and data across multiple SAP applications. To achieve this, robust IAM architecture ensures:
Cross-domain access without compromising security.
Consistent user experience across integrated apps.
Compliance with enterprise cybersecurity standards.

🔑 Core IAM Components
SAP Cloud Identity Services
Joule uses these services as its user store, enabling centralized identity management and role-based access.
OpenID Connect (OIDC)
The recommended protocol for secure integration between Joule and SAP Business AI.
Role Mapping & Session Management
Content is exposed based on role names, and user-to-role assignments occur dynamically during sessions.

🛠 Integration Flow
Initial Setup: Configure Joule with SAP Cloud Identity Services.
Common Data Model (CDM): Define which Joule functions map to specific roles.
Cross-Application IAM: Once the first app integrates with Joule, subsequent apps reuse the same IAM patterns.

🌐 Navigation & Access
SAP Joule leverages SAP Build Work Zone for unified navigation across applications, ensuring smooth transitions for end users.

💡 Why This Matters
IAM for Joule isn’t just about authentication—it’s about enabling secure, intelligent collaboration across SAP’s ecosystem. As AI becomes central to enterprise workflows, IAM ensures trust, compliance, and scalability.

👉 What’s your take? How do you see IAM evolving as AI-driven platforms like Joule become mainstream?

entry.title: Need help with PRD Audit report on iContent Server use
entry.content:
We have seen a sharp increase in teams loading content into SuccessFactors and we need a reliable audit report to review which files on our iContent server are in use and which are not.

We can pull the list of Content Object/Folders from iContent, but a report on Items which Content Objects linked has proven very difficult to create. I received a report from the Learning SIG, but it doesn't list the ITEM ID. 

  1. Because we also have LinkedIn Learning creating Items in the System, I added a search field for Item ID which then required I add a security profile/line.  I think this is interfering as well.
  2. I tried to link the correct table/columns in and now it either will pull only inactive items or a blank report no matter what I put (or leave blank!) for Item IDs

I need help creating this audit report. Here is my PRD Query:

SELECT 
    pc.CPNT_ID,
    pc.CPNT_TYP_ID,
    pc.COMMENTS,
    pc.CPNT_TITLE,
    pc.REV_DTE, 
    pc.REV_NUM,
    pc.NOTACTIVE as "Item Inactive",
    pc.CPNT_LEN,
pcm.MASTERY_SCORE, 
pcm.COMPLETE_ON_LAUNCH, 
pcm.NODE_NO, 
pcm.MODULE_NAME, 
pcm.EXAM_REVW_ENABLED,                
pca.APP_ID, 
pca.APP_TITLE, 
pca.DESCRIPTION,
pca.IS_ONLINE, 
pca.PRIMARY_PARAM,
pca.SECONDARY_PARAMS, 
pca.ENABLE_MOBILE_ACCESS
 
FROM PA_CPNT pc
 
LEFT JOIN PA_CBT_CPNT_MOD pcm ON pc.CPNT_ID = pcm.CPNT_ID
LEFT JOIN PA_CBT_APPLICATION pca ON pcm.APP_ID = pca.APP_ID
WHERE pc.NOTACTIVE = 'N'
 AND pc.REV_NUM = (
        SELECT MAX(REV_NUM) 
        FROM PA_CPNT 
        WHERE CPNT_ID = pc.CPNT_ID
    )
    /**AND [security:PA_NO_DOMAIN_SECURITY pa]*/
ORDER BY pc.CPNT_ID
